issues.title: To what extent should we describe NTRU
issues.author: sfluhrer
issues.body:
One issue is that, without NIST approval, there is not really definitive definition of NTRU.  The closest would be the NIST Round 3 submission, however the description there is targeted towards cryptographers/mathematicians, and I believe that a standard security engineer would not be able to understand it.  Should we try to write up an equivalent definition (targeted towards engineers without extensive math background)?
Should we include reference code (either in addition to or instead of the above description)?  Or, should we point people to the reference code in the Round 3 submission?

issues.title: Should we include the NTRU-HPS 4096821 parameter set
issues.author: sfluhrer
issues.body:
According the Daniel Apon (who was at NIST), the HPS4096821 was added at the last minute for the round 3 introduction; apparently, it is gotten fairly light vetting, and it is unclear whether it meets the claimed security goals.
My question: should we include it?  If we do, we need to mention our concerns.

comments.author: claucece
comments.body: Probably not then. But the clarifying text is good!

issues.title: Should we include public and private key encodings?
issues.author: johngray-dev
issues.body: We describe a method in how to genereate the public and private keys, and even how the polynomials are packed into byte arrays.   Should we also include placeholder Object Identifiers for the 3 parameter sets, as well as ASN.1 encodings for the public and private keys (even if they are just OCTET_STRINGS) containing the packed encodings currently specified in the draft.   That would allow us to experiment with NTRU keys and certificate material for various relevant KEM use cases (like we can already do with Kyber today).

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body:
> Do you have an example IETF draft in that format?

You can take a look at the [post quantum signatures draft](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mesur-io/post-quantum-signatures/main/draft-ietf-cose-post-quantum-signatures.md) for an example.

The [mmark syntax documentation](https://mmark.miek.nl/post/syntax/#rfc-7991-xml-output), specifically the [RFC 7991 section](https://mmark.miek.nl/post/syntax/), will be helpful here.

reviews.author: brownoxford
reviews.body:
At some point along the way it looks like we moved from kramdown-rfc to a mix between [kramdown-rfc](https://github.com/cabo/kramdown-rfc)and [mmark](https://mmark.miek.nl/post/syntax) markdown. We need to use one or the other in order to have the workflows run properly.

I suggest moving to mmark syntax, as I was unable to get kramdown-rfc to fully work properly in some quick testing.

```suggestion
This draft documents NTRU as a method for post quantum key encapsulation mechanism (KEM).  The NTRU method from KEM is believed to be IPR free and cryptographically sound for both pre and post quantum threat environments.
```

```suggestion
NIST has run a competition to select postquantum primitives and selected Kyber for KEM.  Kyber unfortunately has plausible patent claims against it and there are currently undisclosed agreements with the patent holders and NIST. It is unknown whether those agreements would be universally acceptable; if not, there will be organizations for which Kyber is unusable until the patents expire.
```
